articles.name: Integrating XM Cyber’s SCM with PhishER
articles.title: Integrating XM Cyber’s SCM with PhishER
articles.body:
You can integrate your XM Cyber Security Control Monitoring (SCM) module into your PhishER console. XM Cyber’s SCM module provides you with insights into the configuration and activation of security controls.

Before You Connect XM Cyber’s SCM to Your PhishER Console

Before you integrate SCM into your PhishER console, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your KSAT console as an admin.
  2. Go to Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to the Account Integrations option on the sidebar.
  4. Click the API option.
  5. Under Product API, click the Product API link. This step will navigate you to the Product API tab on the KnowBe4 APIs page.
  6. Click the Create New API Token button.
  7. Fill in the following fields:
    1. Name: Use a memorable name.
    2. Expiration Date: Choose an expiration date that is far into the future.
    3. User: Enter the user who is creating the API token.
  8. The console will generate an API key. Please save this API key for the next steps.
Note: Make sure that you click Save Changes to save your Account Settings updates.

Connecting XM Cyber’s SCM to Your PhishER Console

Note: Ensure that an admin was previously added to your PhishER console. Only admins can grant users Security Roles, and an admin should also set up this integration. For more information visit our PhishER Settings Guide.

To connect SCM with your PhishER console, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to XM Cyber’s SCM module as an admin.
  2. In the left menu bar, navigate to System > Tools Configuration.
  3. Select Add Tool.
  4. In the Add Tool dialog box, select SSPM, and then complete the fields as follows:
    1. Vendor: Select KnowBe4.
    2. Type: Select SOAR.
    3. Product Name: Select the Product Name, which is KnowBe4 PhishER.
    4. Version: Select the product version, which is not applicable.
    5. Machine: For a SaaS environment, select the cloud proxy server that XM Cyber gives you. For an on-prem environment, select your cloud proxy server.
    6. Name: You may use the default name or change the name if desired.
  5. Select Save. The tool should now appear on the tool list.
  6. Select the tool from the tool list.
  7. Under the General tab, check the System Active check box and select Apply Changes.
  8. If you are setting the datasource in a SaaS environment:
    1. In the Database field, name the database.
    2. Select Create Database, and then select Save. You should receive a message that you successfully created a database.
  9. In an on-prem environment, expand the database in the Datasource tab and then complete the following fields:
    1. Database Type: PostgreSQL
    2. Server: 127.0.0.1
    3. Port: 5432
    4. Database: You can use any database name you like as long as it contains only lowercase letters. For example, you can use “knowbe4_phisher” as your database name.
    5. User: cyberobserverds
    6. Password: C0DBLocal!
  10. Select the Create Database check box and select Save. You should receive a message that you successfully created a database.
  11. Expand the plugin in the Plugins tab and select Set Parameters. A Plugin Parameters dialog box will appear.
  12. Complete the fields using the API key you retrieved in previous steps.
  13. Select “plugin” to activate the plugin. You should receive a message that you have successfully activated the plugin.
  14. In the Plugins tab, select Save. You should receive a message that you have successfully installed the plugin.
  15. Select “next-1” (Execute) to run this plugin, connect the tool, and collect data. The entry under Last Successful Run will show the date and time the plugin was last run.

articles.name: Defend - Remove Banners for Printing
articles.title: Defend - Remove Banners for Printing
articles.body:
Follow the steps below to remove Defend banners before printing an email:

  1. Open the email you want to print.
  2. Select Send to OneNote in the toolbar above the email.

  3. The email is displayed in OneNote without banners.
  4. Print the email from OneNote.

articles.name: AIDA Policy Quiz Guide
articles.title: AIDA Policy Quiz Guide
articles.body:
You can use our AIDA policy agent to upload and create AIDA policies and policy quizzes. In your KnowBe4 console, you add your AIDA policy as a PDF file and generate a quiz. You can edit and manage quiz questions relating to the policy and then create a training campaign to assign the policy to your users. Once you’ve assigned the policy to a campaign, you can track your users’ progress and acknowledgments. For more information, view our AIDA Policy Quizzes video.

Note: For best results, only upload a policy document. Uploading other types of documents may produce unexpected results or errors.

AIDA is available on the KnowBe4 console as an add-on to your Diamond-level subscription.

Adding AIDA PDF Policies

You have the ability to upload your organization's policies to your console as a PDF file. Use the following steps to upload a policy:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to Training > Policies.
  2. Click the Add AIDA Policy button.
  3. Fill out the fields on the AIDA Policy page.

See the list below for information about each of these fields.

  1. Policy Title: Enter the title of your policy. We recommend including the policy version or creation date in the title. This is the title that will be displayed to your users.
  2. Description (optional): Enter a description of this policy for future reference.
  3. Expected Duration (optional): Specify the minimum number of minutes that users can expect to spend reviewing the policy before they can take the quiz and acknowledge the policy.
  4. Allow Download: If you enable this slider, your users will be able to download the policy from the Policy Viewer interface. For more information about the Policy Viewer, see the User Experience section of the Create and Manage Policies article.
  5. Status: Select the policy status. You can choose Draft, Published, or Archived. For more information about each status, see the Policy Statuses section of this article.
    Note: Policies cannot be published unless they have at least one published language file.

Click Save. The page will update with additional options, including the option to add a language file. See the list below for information about each of these options.

  1. Update Policy: To save your changes, click this button after you update any of the information in the fields above.
  2. + Add Language: Click this button to add a language version of your policy. The Add Language pop-up window will be displayed.
Important: Depending on your organization's needs, you can add as many language versions of your policy as you like. The first version you add will be the default version for all users.

For more information about the fields on the Language Details pop-up window, see the list below.

  1. Policy Name: Enter a name for your policy. This name will be displayed to your users.
  2. Policy File: Click the Browse button to upload a PDF file of your policy.
    Important: If you would like to upload a PDF file that was downloaded from DocuSign, the file must be unsigned. Signed PDF files from DocuSign will not upload successfully.
  3. Language: Select the written language of the policy.
  4. Add text for Accept Policy Checkbox: Enter the text that you want to be displayed next to the acceptance checkbox when your users accept a policy.
  5. Add the acknowledgment text for the policy (optional): This is the text displayed above the Add text for Accept Policy checkbox.
  6. Save and Generate Quiz: Click this button to save this language version of the policy and automatically generate the quiz.

You can edit policies to add additional language versions. For more information, see the Editing AIDA Policies section of this article.

Important: Machine-translated policies may result in poor translation. For optimal results, we recommend having a professional human translator review your policies.
Note:There is a 5 MB file size limit on uploaded PDFs.

Editing AIDA Policies

You can edit the policy details or add additional language versions as needed. Edits to the policy take effect immediately. Users who have already been assigned the policy will be able to see your changes the next time they view it.

Follow the steps below to edit an AIDA policy:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to Training > Policies.
  2. Find the policy you would like to edit from the policy list.
  3. Click the three dots icon next to the AIDA policy you want to edit. See the screenshot and list below for information.

Make a selection:

  • Select Preview to preview the policy and the policy quiz.
  • Select Edit to display the AIDA Policy page. See the screenshot and list below for information about each of these fields.
  • Select Delete to delete the policy.

  1. Policy Title: Enter the title of your policy or agreement. We recommend that you include the policy version or creation date in the title. This title will display on the interface your users will see when reading the policy.
  2. Description (optional): In this field, you can enter a description of this policy for future reference.
  3. Expected Duration (optional): Specify the total time in minutes that users can expect to spend reviewing and acknowledging the policy and taking the quiz.
  4. Allow Download: If you enable this slider, your users will be able to download the policy from the Policy Viewer interface. For more information about the Policy Viewer, see the User Experience section of the Create and Manage Policies article.
  5. Status: Select the policy status. You can choose Draft, Published, or Archived. For more information about each status, see the Policy Statuses section of this article.
  6. Update Policy: To save your changes, click this button after you update any of the information in the fields above.
  7. + Add Language: Click this button to add a language version of your policy. The Add Language pop-up window is displayed.
  8. Actions: Select one of the following actions:
    • Edit File Details: Select this option to edit the details of the language file.
    • Edit Quiz: Select this option to open the quiz editor and edit the policy quiz.
    • Delete: Select this option to delete the language file.
    Note:If the language file is not the default file, you will also have the additional option to Make Default.

Policy Statuses

Your policy can be in one of three statuses: Draft, Published, or Archived. You can change these statuses at any time by editing your policy.

For more information about each of these statuses, see the table below:

Draft

Use this status if you want to save your current policy progress but you don't want the policy to be available when you create a campaign.

Note: A policy can only be placed into draft status if there are no active enrollments on the policy.
Published Use this status when you are ready to use this policy in a campaign. This is the only status that makes the policy available on the Create New Training Campaign page.
Archived Use this status to archive the policy. You cannot assign an archived policy in a new campaign. However, if you include the archived policy in an active campaign, users will still be able to see the policy.

Editing a Policy Quiz

After generating your policy quiz, you can edit it to make sure it fits your organization’s needs.

Follow the steps below to edit a policy quiz:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to Training > Policies.
  2. Find the policy you would like to edit from the policy list.
  3. Select Edit from the Actions menu.


On the AIDA Policy page, scroll to the bottom and then Select Edit Quiz from the Actions menu next to a language file at the bottom of the page to open the quiz editor.


See the list below for information about each of these fields.


  1. All Questions: This is the page's default view. It lists all of the quiz questions available.
  2. Saved Questions: Click this subtab to view the questions you have saved.
  3. Unsaved Questions: Click this subtab to view a list of unsaved questions.
  4. Generate New Questions: Click this button to generate a new quiz based on the same policy.
  5. Questions and answers: This area includes the AIDA-generated questions and multiple-choice answers. Hovering your mouse over a question or an answer will provide additional options:
    • Edit the questions or answers: Click the pencil icon to make the text field next to a question or answer editable. After editing the text, click the check icon to save the new text or the x icon to cancel the edit.
    • Set as correct answer: Click this button to set the response as the correct answer.
  6. Feedback Text: The text that appears after a question is answered.

Saving and Unsaving Questions

Blue bookmark icons next to a question indicate that the question has been saved. Clear bookmark icons indicate that the question has not been saved. Select or clear bookmarks to save and unsave questions.


Editing Policy Quiz Questions and Answers

You can quickly edit questions and answers in the quiz editor. Follow the steps below to edit the quiz questions and answers.

Hover over a question and answer to see the pencil icon, and then click the pencil icon to make the text editable.


Edit the text in the box, then make a selection:

  • Click the check icon to save the edits
  • Click the x icon to cancel the edits.

Publishing a Policy Quiz

After you are satisfied with the quiz questions, scroll to the bottom of the page, then follow the steps below to publish a policy quiz.

  1. Make a selection:
    • Click Save as Draft to save your changes and come back to edit your quiz when you're ready.
    • Click Publish to publish the quiz for use in the console. If the policy is active in any campaigns, the quiz will be immediately available to users in the campaigns. You will return to the AIDA Policy page.
  2. Select Published from the Policy Status drop-down menu.
  3. Click the Update Policy button.

You will be taken to the Policies subtab, and the policy status will show as Published.


For steps on how to assign a policy to your training campaign, see the Assigning Policies section of the Create and Manage Policies article.

articles.name: PhishER Plus Overview
articles.title: PhishER Plus Overview
articles.body:
KnowBe4’s PhishER Plus is available on the PhishER platform as a new subscription or upgrade option for current PhishER customers. Using PhishER Plus, your organization can access crowd-sourced information and tools to strengthen your security measures and defense-in-depth plan. PhishER Plus features allow you to automatically block or remove validated email threats from your users' inboxes. You can also integrate with third-party analysis tools, like CrowdStrike, to provide your organization with security scans and evaluations.

To learn how PhishER Plus features integrate with the PhishER workflow, visit the PhishER Workflow section of our PhishER Product Manual. To view a PhishER product demo, see our KnowBe4 Product Demos article.

To learn the features available in PhishER Plus, see the list below.

  • Global Blocklist: The Global Blocklist uses crowd-sourced information about email threats to help you prevent malicious or spam emails from reaching your users’ inboxes. Once you enable this feature and connect it to your Microsoft 365 mail server, KnowBe4 will connect your mail server to the Global Blocklist. For more information, read our Global Blocklist Guide article.
  • Global PhishRIP: If you enable PhishRIP in your platform, you can enable the Global PhishRIP feature to remove email threats from your user's inboxes before they are reported in your organization. For more information, read our Global PhishRIP Guide article.
  • CrowdStrike Falcon Sandbox: If you have an active CrowdStrike Falcon Intelligence subscription, you can configure the CrowdStrike Falcon Sandbox integration for your PhishER platform. CrowdStrike Falcon Intelligence is a threat intelligence service that combines with the Falcon Sandbox to analyze files and URLs for malicious content in a protected sandbox environment. For more information, read our Integrate CrowdStrike with Your PhishER Platform article.
  • Threat Intel: The Threat Intel feature uses Webroot’s BrightCloud Web Classification & Web Reputation Service to analyze URLs for malicious content. For more information, read our Integrate Threat Intel with Your PhishER Platform article.
  • PhishML Insights: If you enable PhishML in your console, PhishML Insights is automatically enabled. This feature provides an explanation about how PhishML determines if a message is clean, spam, or a threat. For more information, read our PhishML Insights Guide.
  • YARA Rule Generator: The YARA Rule Generator feature simplifies rule creation by automatically generating YARA rule syntax based on your description. For more information, read the Creating Rules Using the YARA Rule Generator section of our Create and Manage PhishER Rules article.

articles.name: Integrate A-LIGN with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.title: Integrate A-LIGN with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.body:
In this article, you’ll learn how to integrate the A-SCEND compliance solution from A-LIGN with your KSAT console. This integration will allow you to automate your compliance requirements using training data from your KSAT console.

Note:Before you set up this integration, you'll need to copy the Reporting API token from your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see the API section of our KSAT Account Settings: Account Integrations article.

To learn how to integrate your KSAT console with A-SCEND, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your A-SCEND Account.
  2. Click the gear icon, then click Integrations.
  3. In the Integration Categories section, click Training.
  4. On the KnowBe4 tile, click Add Integration.
  5. In the Region drop-down menu, select the region of your KSAT instance.
  6. In the API Token field, paste your Reporting API token.
  7. Click Continue.
  8. In the Connection Name field, enter a name for the integration.
    Important:This name can’t be edited after the integration has been made.
  9. Click Link Connection.

After the integration is complete, you’ll see a success message. You can scroll down to the Manage Associated Compliance Engagements section to select which compliance engagements you want the integration to have access to.

To view and manage your KnowBe4 integration, click the gear icon and navigate to Settings > Integrations > My Integrations.

articles.name: Integrate Microsoft Defender for Office 365 with the Phish Alert Button (PAB)
articles.title: Integrate Microsoft Defender for Office 365 with the Phish Alert Button (PAB)
articles.body:
You can integrate the Phish Alert Button (PAB) with Microsoft Defender for Office to send emails to Microsoft’s Submissions page for analysis. In the Microsoft 365 Defender platform, the Submissions page receives emails that users report with Microsoft’s Report button. With this integration, you can allow your users to report suspicious emails to your organization and your Submissions page with the PAB. When users report KnowBe4’s simulated phishing emails with the Report button, Microsoft can mistakenly classify these emails as threats. This integration also helps Microsoft recognize KnowBe4’s simulated phishing emails and avoid false positives for users’ reported emails.

Prerequisites

Before you configure this integration, you'll need to enable and configure the PAB in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see the Enable and Configure section of our Phish Alert Button (PAB) Product Manual.

You'll also need to enable the Microsoft 365 Defender for Office service for your organization’s mail server. Then, configure a security operations (SecOps) mailbox for your Microsoft account so that emails can be sent to your Submissions page. For more information, see Microsoft's Use the Microsoft 365 Defender portal to configure SecOps mailboxes in the advanced delivery policy article.

Important:Microsoft Defender requires that emails be in EML format.

Configuring the Integration

To configure this integration, you’ll need to allow third-party reporting tools for your Microsoft 365 Defender platform. For more information, see Microsoft’s Options for third-party reporting tools article. To allow the third-party reporting tools, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft 365 account using your admin credentials.
  2. Navigate to the Microsoft 365 Defender portal > Settings > Email & collaboration.
  3.  Click User reported settings. Or, you can access the User reported settings page by navigating to https://security.microsoft.com/securitysettings/userSubmission.
  4. On the User reported settings page, select the Monitor reported messages in Outlook check box to enable the reporting options.
  5. Under the Select an Outlook report button configuration section, select Use a non-Microsoft add-in button.
    Important:If you select this option, Microsoft's Report button will be disabled automatically.
  6. Under the Send reported messages to: drop-down menu, select My reporting mailbox only or Microsoft and My reporting mailbox.

    Note:If you select Microsoft and my reporting mailbox, any reported messages will be automatically sent to Microsoft for analysis. For more information, see Microsoft's Options for third-party reporting tools section of their User reported settings article.
  7. In the Add an exchange online mailbox to send reported messages to: field, enter the email address associated with your Microsoft account’s Submissions page and SecOps mailbox.
    Note:Enter the same email address you used to configure your SecOps mailbox. For more information, see Microsoft's Use the Microsoft 365 Defender portal to configure SecOps mailboxes in the advanced delivery policy article.
  8. (Optional) You can select the Allow reporting for quarantined messages. Only admins can report quarantined Teams messages. check box to allow your users to report emails from their quarantine folder.

After you have configured these settings in Microsoft 365 Defender, you’ll need to configure the integration in your KSAT console. To configure the integration in KSAT, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Click your email address in the top-right corner of the page. From the drop-down menu that opens, select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to Account Integrations > Phish Alert.
  4. Click the plus icon next to the PAB instance to view your settings.
  5. Select the Enable Microsoft 365 Defender Integration check box.
  6. In the Submit Reported Emails to: field, enter the email address associated with your Microsoft account’s Submissions page and SecOps mailbox.
    Important:In addition to entering the email address associated with your Microsoft account, you can enter a different email address in the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field to provide a copy of users’ reported emails to your organization’s admins. If you only want to send reported emails directly to your SecOps mailbox, leave the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field empty.
  7. (Optional) You can select the Save a copy of reported emails check box if you would like the PAB to save a copy of reported emails in the Sent folder of the user who reported them.
  8. Click the Save Phish Alert Settings button.
  9. At the bottom of the page, click the Save Changes button.

User Experience

Once you've configured the integration, your users can use the PAB to report suspicious emails to both KnowBe4 and Microsoft.

When a user reports an email, they must select a disposition. By default, they can select the Phishing/Suspicious or Spam/Junk disposition. If you have enabled the User Comments and Email Disposition feature, your users can also add comments and select the Unknown disposition.

If a user selects the Unknown disposition, the reported email is initially labeled as Phishing in Microsoft’s Submissions page. For more information, see our Phish Alert Button (PAB) User Comments and Email Disposition Guide.

Note:Microsoft’s Submissions page cannot receive emails that contain multiple attachments or files with comments. If a user adds a comment when they report an email, the comment file will not be included in the copy of the reported email sent to the Submissions page.

After a user reports an email, the email will be deleted from their inbox, and two copies of the reported emails will be sent. The first copy will be sent to the email address entered in the Send Non-Simulated Emails to: field in your KSAT Account Settings. The second copy will be sent to the email address in the Submit Reported Emails to: field in your KSAT Account Settings, associated with Microsoft Defender’s Submissions page. If the Save a copy of reported emails setting is enabled, a copy of the reported email is also saved in the user’s Sent folder.

Once an email is submitted to Microsoft, it will display in the User reported tab on the Submissions page of your Microsoft 365 Defender portal within a few minutes.

articles.name: PhishER Settings: Integrations
articles.title: PhishER Settings: Integrations
articles.body:
In the Integrations section of your PhishER Settings, you can view and manage integrations with your mail server, the third-party integrations supported by PhishER, and the integration with your KSAT console.

Tip:For more information about specific PhishER integrations, see the Integrations subsection of our Knowledge Base.

Mail Servers

The Mail Servers subtab displays the mail servers connected to your PhishER platform. From this subtab, you can connect and manage your Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace mail server instances. After you connect your mail server instances on this subtab, you can enable PhishRIP or the PhishER Blocklist for your platform.

Once you connect a mail server to a feature on your PhishER platform, you can edit and test the connection. If you update a mail server instance, the instance will automatically update across your PhishER platform. You can also connect mail servers from the Blocklist or PhishRIP subtabs of your PhishER Settings.

To learn how to connect and manage mail servers, see the subsections below.

Connecting a Microsoft 365 Mail Server

To connect a new instance of your Microsoft 365 mail server, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER platform.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Mail Servers.
  3. If you would like to connect to PhishRIP, click New PhishRIP Connection and follow the steps in the Enabling for Microsoft 365 section of our How to Use PhishRIP article. If you would like to connect to the PhishER Blocklist, click New Blocklist Connection and follow the steps in the Blocklist section of this article.

Connecting a Google Workspace Mail Server

To connect a new instance of your Google Workspace mail server, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER platform.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Mail Servers.
  3. Click the New PhishRIP Connection button and follow the steps in the Enabling for Google Workspace section of our How to Use PhishRIP article.

Managing Your Mail Servers

Once you connect a mail server instance, it will display on the Mail Servers page. If you edit or delete a mail server instance, the changes will automatically apply to your PhishER platform. If you disconnect an instance, it will continue to display on the Mail Servers page until you delete it or reconnect it.

To learn more about the settings on the Mail Servers page, see the screenshot and list below.

  1. New PhishRIP Connection and New Blocklist Connection: You can click these buttons to add a new mail server instance or reconnect a disconnected instance. For more information about connecting an instance, see the above subsections of this article.
  2. Pencil icon: You can click this icon to customize the name of a mail server instance.
  3. Test PhishRIP Connection: You can click this link to confirm that a mail server is connected to your PhishER platform. The date and time of when the connection was successfully tested will display next to the link. User Mailboxes Scanned will display the number of mailboxes scanned when the connection was tested.
  4. Funnel icon: You can click this icon to open the User Mailboxes Selection pop-up window. In the pop-up window, you can enter email domains or regular expressions in the fields to indicate the user mailboxes that PhishRIP can scan. For more information, read the User Mailboxes Selection section below.
  5. Disconnect PhishRIP and Disconnect Blocklist: You can click these buttons to disconnect a mail server from PhishRIP or the PhishER Blocklist.
  6. Trash can icon: You can click this icon to delete a disconnected mail server instance.

Selecting User Mailboxes

After the first PhishRIP query is run, your mail server instance will display a funnel icon. You can click the icon to open the User Mailboxes Selection pop-up window. This pop-up window displays the email domains or regular expressions that indicate the user mailboxes that PhishRIP can scan. You can enter email domains in the Domain Scan List field or enter regular expressions in the Regular Expression Scan List field. Enter each value on a separate line. Then, click Save to save your changes. PhishRIP queries will only search in mailboxes of users who have a matching domain or regex string from the lists. If you want PhishRIP queries to search in all the available user mailboxes, remove all entries from both fields.

Blocklist

From the Blocklist subtab, you can enable the PhishER Blocklist feature. This feature helps your mail server prevent malicious or spam emails from reaching your users’ inboxes. With this feature, you can block emails from senders, domains, URLs, and file hashes.

If you have a PhishER Plus subscription, you can also enable the Global Blocklist feature, which connects your mail server to a blocklist managed by KnowBe4's Threat Research Lab. If you enable the Global Blocklist and PhishRIP in your platform, you can enable the Global PhishRIP feature to remove email threats from your user's inboxes using the Global Blocklist. For more information about these features, see our How to Use the Global Blocklist and How to Use Global PhishRIP articles.

Note:To enable the PhishER Blocklist and Global Blocklist in your PhishER platform, your organization must have an active Microsoft 365 instance that is tied to your organization’s domain.

To enable your blocklist, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER platform.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Blocklist.
  3. Click the Connect to Microsoft 365 button. This button will take you to the Microsoft 365 login page.
  4. Once you have logged in, the Permissions requested Accept for your organization pop-up window will display. Once you've read the permissions, click the Accept button.
  5. Turn on the toggle next to Disabled.
  6. From the Blocklist Entry Duration drop-down menu, select the amount of time that you would like entries to remain on your blocklist. A duration of 60 days is selected by default.
  7. Click Save.

Once the PhishER Blocklist is enabled, a block icon will display in the navigation panel on the left side of your PhishER platform. You can click this icon to access your blocklist.

After you enable the PhishER Blocklist, you will need to assign the Exchange Administrator role to the PhishER Blocklist application to authenticate it.

Note: If you enable the Global Blocklist after setting up the PhishER Blocklist, you won't need to repeat the steps for connecting your mail server and assigning the Exchange Administrator role.

To assign the Exchange Administrator role to the application, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to the Microsoft Entra admin center using your admin credentials. You must have at least a Privileged Authentication Administrator role.
  2. Navigate to Microsoft Entra ID > Identity > Roles & admins > Roles & admins.
  3. Click the Exchange Administrator role name and click Add assignments.
  4. In the search bar, enter "PhishER Blocklist" and click Add.

Once you’ve completed the steps above, you can add and manage blocklist entries. For more information about using your blocklist, see our How to Use the PhishER Blocklist article.

CrowdStrike

From the CrowdStrike subtab, you can configure your integration with CrowdStrike Falcon Sandbox. CrowdStrike Falcon Intelligence is a threat intelligence service that combines with the Falcon Sandbox to analyze files and URLs for malicious content. To integrate the CrowdStrike Falcon Sandbox with PhishER, you must have a PhishER Plus subscription and an active CrowdStrike Falcon Intelligence subscription. If you do not have a CrowdStrike subscription, you can purchase one on CrowdStrike’s website.

For more information about integrating CrowdStrike with your PhishER platform, see our How to Integrate CrowdStrike with Your PhishER Platform article.

VirusTotal

From the VirusTotal subtab, you can configure your integration with VirusTotal. VirusTotal is a service that uses over 70 antivirus scanners to inspect and analyze files for malicious content. To integrate your VirusTotal account with PhishER, you must have an active VirusTotal license key. If you do not have a VirusTotal account, you can join for free on VirusTotal's website.

For more information about integrating VirusTotal with your PhishER platform, see our VirusTotal and PhishER Integration article.

Threat Intel

From the Threat Intel subtab, you can configure your integration with Threat Intel. Threat Intel uses Webroot’s BrightCloud Web Classification & Web Reputation Service to analyze URLs. To configure Threat Intel with your PhishER platform, you must have a PhishER Plus subscription. For more information about integrating Threat Intel with your PhishER platform, see our Integrate Threat Intel with Your PhishER Platform article.

Syslog

From the Syslog subtab, you can configure the Syslog servers connected to your PhishER platform. System Logging Protocol, or Syslog, is a protocol that generates logs for network devices or servers. You can integrate Syslog servers with your PhishER account to log when PhishER actions are triggered.

For more information about integrating Syslog servers with your PhishER platform, see our How to Integrate Syslog with Your PhishER Platform article.

Webhooks

From the Webhooks subtab, you can configure the webhooks connected to your PhishER platform. A webhook, also known as an HTTP push API, allows applications to provide other applications with information in real time. You can receive a callback based on a PhishER action that is attached to a message.

For more information about configuring webhooks for your PhishER platform, see our How to Create and Manage Webhooks in Your PhishER Platform article.

Cyren Inbox Security (CIS)

When using Cyren Inbox Security (CIS), you have the option to send scanned or reported emails to your PhishER platform. For more information about this feature, see our Cyren Inbox Security (CIS) Integration article.

KSAT Console

From the KSAT Console subtab, you can configure your integration with your KSAT console to update events on KSAT User Timelines. If you have a Platinum or Diamond-level subscription, you can use the KSAT integration option to see two types of events on your users' KSAT User Timelines. The first event is the disposition of the messages that your users have reported with the Phish Alert Button (PAB). The second event is the disposition and location of a message that PhishRIP has quarantined.

For more information about the settings on the KSAT Console subtab, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. User Event API Key: This field displays the last four characters of your User Event API Key. To update this field, click Update Key. In the Update Key pop-up window that opens, enter your User Event API Key in the New User Event API Key field and click Save.
    Note:You can find your User Event API Key in the User Event API section of your KSAT Account Settings.
  2. Send Events to KSAT via PhishER Actions: Select this check box to enable the Send to KSAT option for PhishER actions. You can use this option to send information to your KSAT console when users report a message with the PAB.
  3. Automatically send PhishRIP Events to KSAT Console: Select this check box to send information to your KSAT console when PhishRIP quarantines a message. The event on your User Timelines will display the message’s disposition and the location where it was found in the user's inbox.
    Note:You must enable PhishRIP to use the Automatically send PhishRIP Events to KSAT Console integration feature. Leaving the Automatically send PhishRIP Events to KSAT Console check box deselected will not prevent you from seeing the disposition of reported emails on the KSAT User Timeline.
  4. Exclude emails from Sent, Spam, Deleted, and Quarantine folders: Select this check box to exclude information from emails that were found in your users’ Sent, Spam, Deleted, or Quarantine folders.
  5. Send PhishRIP events to KSAT when the Source of the PhishRIP query is labeled as: You can select specific dispositions if you would like to send information about messages that received a specific disposition only.
  6. Save: Click this button to update your KSAT integration settings.

articles.name: SecurityCoach Information Placeholders Overview
articles.title: SecurityCoach Information Placeholders Overview
articles.body:
You can use SecurityCoach information placeholders to populate specific information in your SecurityTip notifications. These placeholders pull information from the triggered detection rule that initiates the SecurityTip. For general information about placeholders, see our Placeholders Guide.

Note:You can only use SecurityCoach information placeholders in SecurityTip notification templates. These placeholders are not available in training notifications.

For information about each of the SecurityCoach information placeholders, see the table below:

Placeholder Name Placeholder Drop-Down Menu Option Information Populated
[[log_type]] Log Type

This placeholder populates the vendor’s security type.

For more information, see our Vendor Security Types article.
[[vendor]] Vendor This placeholder populates the vendor’s name.
[[rule]] Detection Rule This placeholder populates the detection rule’s name.
[[category]] Rule Category

This placeholder populates the threat category of the detection rule.

For example, the category may be malware or online safety.
[[detection_datetime]] Detection Time This placeholder populates the date and time that the rule detection occurred.
[[detection_category]] Detection Category This placeholder populates the threat category of the detected vendor event.
[[detection_severity]] Detection Severity

This placeholder populates the threat severity of the rule detection.

Threat severities include low, medium, high, and critical.
[[event_file_name]] Event File Name

This placeholder populates the name of the file that triggered the detection rule.
[[domain_visited]] Domain Visited

This placeholder populates the domain that triggered the detection rule.
[[email_subject]] Email Subject

This placeholder populates the subject of the email that triggered the detection rule.
[[callback_phishing_phone_number]] Callback Phone Number

This placeholder populates the callback phishing phone number that the user contacted to trigger the detection rule.

articles.name: SecurityCoach Change Log
articles.title: SecurityCoach Change Log
articles.body:
Use this article to stay up-to-date with changes to KnowBe4's SecurityCoach product.

Note: Changes to SecurityCoach may include new, updated, deprecated, or removed features. KnowBe4 reserves the right to terminate access to, use of, and support of features that are included as part of the Subscription Services, which is common with SaaS services as they are constantly changing and improving. This allows us to adapt to the evolving cybersecurity industry so we can provide current, high-quality services.

See the table below for a list of updates, with the latest updates displaying at the top.

Release Date Description
November 2025
  • November 25, 2025 - We’ve updated our recommended API token configuration for Netskope to align with Netskope’s best practices and ensure integration security. Existing Netskope integrations are not affected by this change. To set up a new Netskope integration, follow the steps in our Netskope Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • November 19, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Google IAM! Now, you can send Google IAM event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • November 12, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Okta! Now, you can send Okta event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
October 2025
  • October 8, 2025 - We’ve updated two SecurityCoach report types to Svelte: Detection Rules Activity Reports and Real-Time Coaching Activity Reports! This update changes the appearance of both report types in the SecurityCoach tab, enhancing user navigation and enabling easier report filtering and downloading. To learn more, see our Detection Rules Activity Reports article and our Real-Time Coaching Activity Reports article.
September 2025
  • September 22, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Zscaler! Now, you can send Zscaler event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • September 11, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Sophos! Now, you can send Sophos Capture Client event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • September 2, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for SentinelOne! Now, you can send SentinelOne event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • September 1, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Google! Now, you can send Google event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
August 2025
  • August 6, 2025 - We’ve added a new Splunk integration feature for Cisco Umbrella! Now, you can send Cisco Umbrella event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
July 2025
  • July 30, 2025 - We’ve updated our API token configurations for Code42 Incydr to align with Code42’s API updates and ensure integration stability. Customers affected by this update will find an alert in their SecurityCoach console with instructions to update their Code42 API permissions by following the steps in our Code42 Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • July 25, 2025 - We’ve improved SecurityCoach data for your users' timelines! Now, SecurityTip previews will display in the target user’s language, so that you can see the exact SecurityTip content that was delivered. For more information, see the User Timeline Subtab section of our User Profile Guide.
June 2025
  • June 25, 2025 - We’ve added new SecurityCoach Notifications and Alerts! Now, admins and Security Role users can subscribe to receive important messages and insights from SecurityCoach. These include notifications for critical alerts, integration health, system detection rules, user management, and real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our new Personal Settings Guide.
  • June 20, 2025 - We’ve added a Microsoft Edge for Business integration! Now, you can use data from Microsoft Edge for Business in real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Microsoft Edge for Business Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • June 4, 2025 - We've added a new Splunk integration feature for Crowdstrike! Now, you can send Crowdstrike event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
May 2025
  • May 22, 2025 - We’ve updated our API token configurations for Crowdstrike Falcon Insight to align with Crowdstrike’s API updates and ensure integration stability. Customers affected by this update will find an alert in their SecurityCoach console with instructions to set up a new Crowdstrike integration by following the steps in our Crowdstrike Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • May 20, 2025 - We've added new SecurityTips for reporting phishing simulations! Now, you can use these new SecurityTips to automatically congratulate users for correctly reporting simulated phishing emails, which will help encourage this key security habit. For more information, see our SecurityTips Guide.
  • May 14, 2025 - We've added new SecurityTips to coach your users on their simulated phishing tests! Now, if a user fails a phishing test, you can send a dynamic GIF that will reveal the Social Engineering Indicators they missed for the exact test they received. For more information, see our Real-Time Coaching with Social Engineering Indicators (SEI) article.
  • May 7, 2025 - We've added new Splunk integration features for Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, and Microsoft Entra ID Protection! Now, you can send associated vendor event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • May 5, 2025 - We’ve updated our API token configurations for Microsoft 365 and Defender for Cloud Apps (formerly MCAS) to align with Microsoft’s API updates and ensure integration stability. Customers affected by this update will find an alert in their SecurityCoach console with instructions to add new API permissions by following the steps in our Microsoft 365 and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
April 2025
  • April 2, 2025 - We've improved and expanded the Unmapped Vendor Data Report (formerly the Unmapped Events Report)! Now, you can use the report to view unmapped vendor data and map the risky activity to your KSAT users. For more information, see our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.
March 2025
  • March 31, 2025 - We've added a new Graph API for SecurityCoach! Now, you can use GraphQL to call and interact with your SecurityCoach data. For more information, see our KnowBe4 Graph API Overview article.
  • March 19, 2025 - We've added new SecurityCoach data fields for Microsoft Entra ID and Okta SCIM user provisioning! Now, you can sync more SecurityCoach fields with SCIM to better map your users to their risky activity. For more information, see our Configure SCIM for Microsoft Entra ID and Configure SCIM for Okta articles.
February 2025
  • February 25, 2025 - We've added a new Splunk integration feature for Bitdefender GravityZone and Cloudflare Area 1 Email Security! Now, you can send associated vendor event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • February 17, 2025 - We've added event metadata to the Real-Time Coaching Activity report! Now, you can view event metadata on the report page to better understand why a SecurityTip was sent. For more information, see our Customize and View the Real-Time Coaching Activity Report article.
  • February 12, 2025 - We've added a new Splunk integration feature for Microsoft 365 and Palo Alto Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW)! Now, you can send associated vendor event data from Splunk to SecurityCoach for use in your real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • February 10, 2025 - We've added a new system rule for mapping your users! Now, SecurityCoach will automatically connect hostnames received from your integrated vendors to their associated KSAT users. For more information, see the Configuring User Mapping Rules section of our Map Users in SecurityCoach article.
January 2025
  • January 29, 2025 - We've added event metadata to the CSV file version of the Detection Rules Activity Report! Now, when you generate a CSV file for the report, you can view event metadata in the file. For more information, see the Viewing Detection Rules Activity Reports section of our Customize and View Detection Rules Activity Reports article.
Release Date Description
December 2024
  • December 12, 2024 - We've enhanced the Microsoft Teams integration for SecurityCoach! Now, you can view more details of your user sync, including a downloadable CSV file of any user sync errors. You can also resync your integrated users and teams on demand, allowing you to more quickly adjust your user list and resolve errors. For more information, see our Microsoft Teams Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • December 6, 2024 - We've added PasswordIQ events to SecurityCoach! Now, Diamond-level customers can use PasswordIQ data for weak, breached, or shared passwords in real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see the KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) section of our System Detection Rules by Vendor article.
October 2024
  • October 30, 2024 - We've added callback phishing events to SecurityCoach! Now, Diamond-level customers can use KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) callback phishing data in real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our System Detection Rules by Vendor article.
  • October 23, 2024 - We've enhanced the ingestion of events into SecurityCoach! The SecurityCoach Vendor Events Report has been refined to focus only on coaching events that are linked to detection rules. This new filtering prioritizes the events that are most relevant to your users. To include more events in your report, visit the Creating a Custom Detection Rule section of our Detection Rules Guide to create and link detection rules to the events.
September 2024
  • September 23, 2024 - We've added video content for SecurityTips! Now, you can coach your users about risky behavior by sending SecurityTips with videos. We have over 50 new and exclusive SecurityCoach videos ready for use, including our new ClickBait series! For more information, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.
  • September 18, 2024 - We've added user feedback for SecurityTips! Now you can allow your users to provide acknowledgment and feedback for any SecurityTips they receive. For more information, see our User Feedback Interactions article.
August 2024
  • August 12, 2024 - We've added a Palo Alto Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) integration! Now, you can use data from Palo Alto NGFW in real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our Palo Alto Cloud Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
July 2024
  • We've enhanced the metadata passed from the KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training console to SecurityCoach. This metadata now includes the following additional fields:
    • Campaign name of the Phishing Security Test (PST)
    • Client IP address of the failure
    • Email subject of the PST template
    • Event threat category for simulated phishing
    • Sender email address of the PST template
    • Visited domain name of the failure
  • This information can be used to create custom detection rules and SecurityTip placeholders for visited domain names and email subjects.
June 2024
  • We've added a Test Mode feature to SecurityCoach. Now, you can see how your real-time coaching campaign will behave before you begin coaching your users. To learn more about this feature, see our Working with Test Mode Campaigns article.
May 2024
  • We've added a Mimecast integration! For more information, see our Mimecast Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
April 2024
  • We've created a learner support article for SecurityCoach so you can show your users what their SecurityTips and training notifications will look like. For more information, see our Learner Support: SecurityCoach Notifications article.
March 2024
  • We've released improvements to the layout of our individual real-time coaching campaign overview pages! To learn more, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide.
February 2024
  • We've added a FortiGate Cloud integration! For more information, see our FortiGate Cloud Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've updated our User Event API to allow admins to push external events to SecurityCoach! Now you can push any event into SecurityCoach to use for detection rules and in real-time coaching campaigns. For more information, see our User Event API documentation.
  • We've updated our Real-Time Coaching Overview page to enhance the usability for admins. For more information, read about our Individual Real-Time Coaching Campaign Overview.
January 2024
  • We've released changes to the layout of the Reports tab in SecurityCoach to enhance the usability of the page. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview.
  • We've released two new system rules for mapping user email aliases to events in SecurityCoach. For more information, read about our System User Mapping Rules.
  • We've released the ability to search for a user on the Detection Rules Activity Reports in SecurityCoach. For more information, see our How to Customize and View Detection Rules Activity Reports for SecurityCoach article.
Release Date Description
December 2023
  • You can now configure your user mapping rules on the same page as your vendor integration. For a list of available vendor integrations and their type, see our Vendor Security Types article.
November 2023
  • We've added a Live View toggle for the Vendor Events Report in SecurityCoach! With this toggle, you can view events as they happen. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview article.
  • We've added the Google Chat integration! For more information, see our Google Chat Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've updated our SecurityCoach integration method with Sophos! For more information, see our updated Sophos Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've released a Top Recommendation card in SecurityCoach! Now you can use this card to create a recommended real-time coaching campaign based on detection rules that haven't been used yet in a campaign. For more information about recommended campaigns, see our Creating and Managing Real-Time Coaching Campaigns article.
October 2023
  • We've improved the setup process for SecurityCoach! Now you'll be guided through the initial SecurityCoach setup in just four easy steps. As you complete each step, you can mark it as complete in the new SecurityCoach Setup section of your dashboard. You can also keep track of your progress using the new setup progress bar at the top of your screen. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Quickstart Guide.
  • We've removed 2 detection rules and added a new detection rule for Microsoft 365. For more information, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.
September 2023
  • We've added a KSAT integration! For more information see our KSAT Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • You can now upload custom graphics for SecurityTips! For more information, see our How to Upload Custom SecurityTip Graphics article.
  • We've improved our process for integrating Microsoft Teams with SecurityCoach! For more information, visit our Microsoft Teams Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
July 2023
  • We've added alt text to SecurityTips! Now, SecurityTips are accessible for users with screen readers.
June 2023
  • We've added GIFs to SecurityTips! Now you can send your users SecurityTips in GIF format. For more information see our Creating and Managing Real-Time Coaching Campaigns article.
May 2023
  • We've added a webhook integration for Cloudflare Area 1 email security! For more information, see our Cloudflare Area 1 Email Security Integration Guide for SecurityCoach article.
  • We've added the Cloudflare Zero Trust integration! For more information, see our Cloudflare Zero Trust Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
March 2023
  • We've added 2 new topics for SecurityTip graphics: Social Website and Shopping Website. We also updated the Alcohol/Nicotine Website topic to Alcohol/Drug Website.
  • We've added 6 new SecurityTip graphics! These graphics cover a range of topics, including restricted websites and online safety.
  • We've added the Bitdefender GravityZone integration! For more information, see our Bitdefender GravityZone Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've added the new Vendor Events Report! You can use this report to view detailed event data from your integrated vendors. For more information, see our SecurityCoach Reporting Overview article.
February 2023
  • We've added 10 new SecurityTip graphics! These graphics cover a range of topics, including cryptomining websites, video streaming websites, cloud permissions, malware, and email safety.
  • We've added new operators that you can use to create criteria for your detection rules! For a full list of available operators, see our Creating and Managing Detection Rules article.
  • We've added the option to update your Netskope integration with a new Tenant Name and API token. For more information, see our Netskope Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've added the option to update your Cisco Umbrella integration with a new API key and API secret. For more information, see our Cisco Umbrella Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
January 2023
  • We've added new SecurityCoach information placeholders that you can use in your SecurityTip notifications! These placeholders pull information from the triggered detection rule that initiated the SecurityTip. For more information, see our How to Use SecurityCoach Information Placeholders article.
  • We've added the Cloudflare Area 1 Email Security integration! For more information, see our Cloudflare Area 1 Email Security Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.
  • We've released the new Limit to 1 SecurityTip per day option for real-time coaching campaigns! You can enable this option for a campaign to send only one SecurityTip per user in a 24-hour period. For more information, see our Creating and Managing Real-Time Coaching Campaigns article.
  • We've added 5 new detection rules and removed 1 detection rule for Microsoft Office 365. For more information, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.
  • Bookmark this page to learn about SecurityCoach updates.

articles.name: KnowBe4 Console Account Settings: User Management
articles.title: KnowBe4 Console Account Settings: User Management
articles.body:
In this article, you'll learn about the User Management section of your KSAT Account Settings. In the User Management section, you can update your user provisioning settings and your general user settings.

User Provisioning

In the User Provisioning section, you can edit your user provisioning settings. You have the ability to use Active Directory Integration (ADI), SCIM, or Google User Provisioning (GUP) to provision your users.

See below for more information about the settings in this section:

  1. Enable User Provisioning: Select this check box if you would like to use Active Directory (AD), SCIM, or Google User Provisioning (GUP) to manage your users. After you select this check box and save your Account Settings, you'll have access to a new Provisioning subtab. To access this subtab in your console, navigate to Users > Provisioning.
  2. Test Mode: This check box is selected by default. We recommend that you keep this check box selected until you’re satisfied with the results of your sync. If you use test mode, you have the ability to view details about your sync and what actions would have occurred if test mode was disabled. To see these details, navigate to Users > Provisioning.
  3. Active Directory Integration Settings: Select Active Directory Integration (ADI) to show this menu and see options for syncing with ADI.
    1. Show Group Domain: If your users are split between multiple domain sources, you can select this check box to add the root domain to each of the AD-synced group names in the KSAT console. Adding the root domain allows you to better organize your users.
    2. ADI Sync Token: This is the unique account token you'll need during the ADI installation process. You can generate a new token by clicking the Regenerate ADI Token button.
      Important:Please be aware that if you regenerate your ADI Sync token, you will not be able to sync your Active Directory until you update your Active Directory Sync Tool with the new sync token. We recommend that you only regenerate your ADI token to stop existing syncs from a tool that you don't know the location of. For more information about ADI, see our Active Directory Integration (ADI) Configuration Guide.
    3. Download Active Directory Sync Tool: Select this button to download and install the ADI sync tool.
  4. SCIM: Select SCIM to show this menu and see options for syncing with SCIM.
    1. Tenant URL: In this section, you can enter your tenant URL to connect KSAT with your identity provider.
    2. Generate SCIM Token: Select this button to generate a new SCIM token. This token can only be viewed once, so you'll need to make sure to save the information before closing the window. If you regenerate a SCIM token, you'll need to be sure to update your identity provider with the most recent token. For more information, see ourSCIM Configuration Guide.
  5. Google User Provisioning Settings: Select Google to show this menu and see options for syncing with Google User Provisioning.
    1. View Setup Process: Select this drop-down menu to see the steps for configuring your Google Workspace Admin console.
    2. Google Workspace Customer ID: You can enter your Google Workspace Customer ID here. You can find it by logging in at Google's Admin page and then clicking Account > Account Settings.
    3. Google Workspace Admin Email Address: In this field, you can enter your Google Workspace Admin Email Address. For more information, see our Google User Provisioning (GUP) Guide.

User Provisioning Notifications

In the User Provisioning Notifications section, you can enable notifications to alert users if your organization doesn’t receive a user provisioning sync within a selected time frame. Notifications include an email alert and a banner at the top of the KSAT console.

See below for more information about the settings in this section:

  1. Enable User Provisioning Notifications: Select this check box to enable user provisioning notifications.
  2. Time Frame: Select the amount of time that should pass before alerting users that a user provisioning sync has not been received. For example, if you would like to be notified if a sync hasn’t been received in 48 hours, select 48 hours.
  3. Notification Recipients: Enter the email addresses of users you would like to receive notifications.

User Settings

In the User Settings section, you can edit user and admin permissions.

See below for more information about the settings in this section:

  1. Allow Users to Create Accounts: Select this check box to allow your users to create their own accounts. We recommend that you only enable this setting in special cases.
  2. Use Password-less Login: Select this check box to allow users to log in to the Learner Experience (LX) without entering a password. If you enable this setting, make sure to use training notifications that have the "password-less" tag. You can also create your own training notifications using our Password-less Link placeholders. For more information, see our Enable and Use Password-Less Logins article.
    1. Disable Password-less Login for Admins: Select this check box to disable password-less logins for admins.
    2. Disable Automatic Email Generation for Password-less Login: Selecting this option will require users to select the Next button on the login page to receive a new password-less login link.
    3. Expire Password-less Link After: If you have enabled password-less logins, this setting defines how long the password-less link will remain active for your users. This duration must be between one and 999 days.
  3. Require users to reset initial password set by admins: Select this check box to allow admins to set users' initial passwords and require users to change their passwords after their first login.
  4. Limit a user's console sessions to one IP address: Select this check box to allow admins to log in to separate instances of the console at the same time, as long as they log in from the same IP address. For more information, see our Session Settings Guide.
  5. Only allow console sessions from specific IP ranges: Select this check box to restrict admin and security role user sessions to the IP addresses entered below. You can either enter the IP addresses individually and separate them with commas, or you can enter a range of IP addresses. For example, you could enter an IP address range of 147.160.167.0/26. If you'd like to enter multiple IP ranges, you can separate each range with commas.
  6. Admin Session Timeout: Select the time period that you'd like admin account sessions to remain active. If the session is still inactive after this time period, admins will be logged out of their accounts. For more information, see our Session Settings Guide.
  7. User Session Timeout: Select the time period that you’d like LX sessions to remain active. If the session is still inactive after this time period, your users will be logged out of their accounts. For more information, see our Session Settings Guide.
  8. Minimum Password Length: Select the minimum length required for user passwords. You can choose between eight and 32 characters.
  9. Require MFA: Select whether Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is required for all users, just for admins, or is not necessary for either group. MFA must be set up the next time they log in. For further instructions regarding restoring a user’s access when this setting is enabled, see the Unlocking a User’s Account section of our Enable Two-Factor or Multi-Factor Authentication on Your Account article.
  10. Remember Trusted Device: If enabled, users and admins only need to log in with MFA once per trusted device for the specified time period below.
  11. Remember Device for: Enter the number of days you want the system to remember MFA for your trusted device.
